[[Louisville, Kentucky]] |death_date= |debutyear=1976 |debutteam=Seattle Seahawks |finalyear=1981 |finalteam=Seattle Seahawks |draftyear=1976 |draftround=2 |draftpick=59 |college=[[Georgia Tech]] |teams= * [[Seattle Seahawks]] ([[1976 NFL season|1976]]-[[1981 NFL season|1981]]) |highlights= *N/A |stat1label=[[Reception (American football)|Reception]]s |stat1value=68 |stat2label=Receiving Yards |stat2value=1,017 |stat3label=[[Touchdowns]] |stat3value=3 |pfr=RaibSt00 |dbf=RAIBLSTE01 }} '''Steve Carl Raible''' (born June 2, 1954) is a former [[NFL]] [[wide receiver]] and currently an anchor for [[KIRO-TV|KIRO 7]] in [[Seattle, Washington|Seattle]], [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]]. He was born in [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]], [[Kentucky]], and attended college at [[Georgia Tech]]. An original member of the [[Seattle Seahawks]] as a second round selection in the [[1976 NFL Draft]] (59th overall), he played [[wide receiver]] from [[1976 NFL season|1976]] to [[1981 NFL season|1981]]. While with the Seahawks, Raible was known more for his locker room antics than his on field play. He now shares duties as one of the co-anchors for the [[KIRO-TV]] team, the lead play-by-play announcer for the Seahawks (the "Voice of the Seahawks") on flagship stations [[KIRO-AM]] (710 ESPN Seattle) and [[KIRO-FM]] (News/Talk 97.3), and an anchor providing in-depth, TV coverage of the [[Seafair]] [[Hydroplane (boat)|hydroplane]] races and [[Blue Angels]] airshow during the first weekend of August each year in Seattle. He shaved his famous mustache in March 2008, due to KIRO 7 making the switch to [[High-definition television|High definition]]. http://blog.seattlepi.com/thebigblog/2008/03/19/why-kiros-steve-raible-lost-his-moustache Raible was the first NFL player from [[Trinity High School (Louisville)|Trinity High School]] in Louisville. ==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://www.kirotv.com/station/1867929/detail.html KIRO-TV profile] * [http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/sports/2009542929_voicesraible27.html ''The Seattle Times''] - profile story - 27-July-2009 {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[Silver Anniversary Awards (NCAA)]] | before=[[Dianne Baker]]
